title: Soldier says losing leg to save tank crew is 'best thing that's happened to him'
text:

A soldier amputated his own leg while trying to free himself from a horror tank crash and save his crew mates.

Ezra Maes, from Colorado, lost his limb while trying to get himself out of the mangled tank to help himself and collegaues.

But he reportedly said the freak accident was an inspiration, has given him a second chance at life and 'probably the best thing that's ever happened to him'.

"I'll probably say that for the rest of my life," he told Fox News.

"Every day I wake up and look at it, and I remember how close I was to losing it all. And I'm still here.

"I managed to survive, and this is just the scar I walked away with."

Maes was stationed in Poland as part of a NATO operation last year when he and two crew members fell asleep in their tank on an overnight training exercise, according to reports.

When they woke up, they found the tank hurtling down a hill as the brakes had failed.

The group had no choice but to brace as they crashed into an embankment at full speed.

Maes was launched forward and his leg was caught in the turret gear - but his concerns remained with his team.

The driver of the tank had reportedly smashed his head through the driver's hatch.

Another had dislocated her leg and was bleeding profusely from a deep cut to her thigh.

Determined to help, Maes maneuvered his body to dislodge himself from the mangled metal.

"I pushed and pulled at my leg as hard as I could to get loose and felt a sharp tear," Maes told the Daily Mail.

"I thought I had dislodged my leg, but when I moved away, my leg was completely gone."

Blood began pouring from his wound but it didn't stop him persevering and he immediately started shock procedures on himself and his crew.

He ordered them to focus on breathing and guided them through making makeshift tourniquets to stem any bleeding.

Maes then managed to call for help.

The soldier was rushed to hospital and spent four months in intensive care.

But he said he and his crew still feel lucky, knowing so much more could have gone wrong.

A year later, Maes continues to have physiotherapy and occupational therapy and works with service dogs.

He is also in the process of being fitted with a prosthetic leg.
description: Ezra Maes reportedly said the freak accident has given him a second chance at life and "this is just the scar I walked away with"
